profileText: a Delegate from Connecticut; born in Durham, Middlesex County, Conn., July 8, 1730; received a thorough English training and graduated from Yale College in 1748; studied law and admitted to the bar; town clerk 1756-1786; justice of the peace in 1762; appointed judge of the New Haven County Court in 1773 and promoted to presiding judge five years later; member of the committee of safety; served in the Revolutionary Army as a colonel and brigadier general of Connecticut Militia, and as a second major general 1777-1779; Member of the Continental Congress 1784; member of the State executive council 1785-1789; State comptroller in 1786 and 1787; member of the State ratification convention in 1788 and opposed adoption of the Constitution; died in Durham, Conn., September 22, 1817; interment in the Old Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: In the Map Collection, 1748, 1 map.
researchRecord.description: A plan of the town of New Haven with all the buildings in 1748, taken by the Honorable General Wadsworth of Durham, to which are added the names and professions of the inhabitants at that period, also the location of lots to many of the first grantees.

researchRecord.name: In the Wadsworth Family Papers, 1764-1800, 12 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers include cases handled by James Wadsworth, Justice of the Peace in Durham, Connecticut, involving punishment meted for stealing a horse, playing cards and breaking curfew.
